Description: THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MATCH A POOL OF NRDA FUNDS WITH EXISTING AVAILABLE LOWER FOX RIVER BASIN TMDL NONPOINT CONSERVATION IMPLEMENTATION GRANTS SUCH AS GLRI AND TRM COST SHARE FUNDING FOR THE ENHANCEMENT OF CONSERVATION BMPS WITH ADDED HABITAT COMPONENTS IN THE MUD CREEK, PLUM CREEK, KANKAPOT CREEK, APPLE CREEK, AND DUCK CREEK WATERSHEDS. TYPICAL PROJECTS INCLUDE STREAMBANK RESTORATION, TWO-STAGE DITCH CONSTRUCTION, CONSTRUCTED WETLANDS, WETLAND RESTORATION, ETC. THESE PROJECTS ARE TYPICALLY LOCATED IN RIPARIAN AREAS AND LANDOWNERS UTILIZE THESE FUNDS TO COMPLIMENT THE CONSERVATION BMPS WITH ENHANCED HABITAT AND NATURE BASED STABILIZATION SOLUTIONS. AN EXAMPLE IS STREAMBANK RESTORATION USING TOEWOOD STRUCTURES IN LIEU OF TRADITIONAL ROCK RIPRAP. WE ANTICIPATE 70  OUTAGAMIE COUNTY GRANT FUNDS WITH 20-30  NRDA GRANT FUNDS, WITH CAREFUL ATTENTION NOT TO EXCEED A 50 50 COMBINATION OF COST-SHARE PROVIDED DEPENDENT ON PROJECT TYPE. PROPOSED PROJECTS WILL BE COMMUNICATED WITH THE NRDA TECHNICAL COMMITTEE FOR APPROVAL IN ADVANCE OF CONTRACTING AND INSTALLATION.IN ADDITION TO COMPLEMENTING CONSERVATION BMPS, WE ALSO FIND VALUE IN HAVING FUNDS AVAILABLE TO LANDOWNERS TO ENTER INTO A PERPETUAL AGREEMENT TO ESTABLISH RIPARIAN BUFFERS WITH NATIVE SPECIES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE U.S. FISH   WILDLIFE PARTNER PROGRAM. THESE RIPARIAN BUFFERS COMPLIMENT CONSERVATION BMPS BY CONNECTING THE HABITAT CREATED WITH RIPARIAN VEGETATION IN SENSITIVE AREAS. LOCATIONS OF THESE BUFFERS WILL BE INCLUDED IN ANNUAL NRDA TECHNICAL COMMITTEE PROJECT VERIFICATION MEETINGS PRIOR TO INSTALL. WE ANTICIPATE INSTALLING 10 ACRES OF PERPETUAL NATIVE RIPARIAN BUFFERS IN IN THE LOWER FOX RIVER BASIN.

WESTERN AND CLARKS GREBE NESTING COLONIES ON LAKE ALMANOR ARE SOME OF THE LARGEST IN THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA. UNFORTUNATELY, THEY ARE SUBJECT TO HUMAN DISTURBANCE RESULTING IN LARGE DECREASES IN REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS. SUCCESSFUL NESTING REQUIRES ISOLATION FROM DISTURBANCE WITH PLENTIFUL OPEN WATER TO ALLOW FOR REARING CHICKS. SITE SELECTION IS GENERALLY REPEATED YEAR AFTER YEAR. SUBMERGED EMERGENT OR ROOTED VEGETATION IS NEEDED TO ANCHOR FLOATING NESTS. FLUCTUATING AND DECREASING WATER LEVELS CAUSED BY WATER MANIPULATION AND DROUGHT CAUSES SERIOUS PROBLEMS FOR NESTING GREBE COLONIES. PLUMAS AUDUBON SOCIETY PROVIDES THIS PROPOSAL AS A MEANS OF PROTECTING WESTERN   CLARKS GREBES FROM HUMAN DISTURBANCE AT LAKE ALMANOR. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PREVENT DISTURBANCE OF NESTS AND TO ENSURE THAT THE JUVENILE ADULT RATIO DOES NOT FALL BELOW .35 DUE TO HUMAN DISTURBANCE IN ANY ONE YEAR, BY CONSTRUCTING NESTING PLATFORMS WITH DECOYS AND CALLS TO ENCOURAGE GREBES TO NEST IN DEEPER WATER WHERE WATER DROPS WILL NOT RESULT IN COMPLETE COLONY ABANDONMENT. IN CONGRUENCE WITH PLUMAS AUDUBON SOCIETY S EDUCATION AND OUTREACH EFFORTS, WHICH INCLUDES THE INSTALLATION OF SIGNAGE, PRODUCTION OF A DISTURBANCE PREVENTION PAMPHLET AND HOSTING THE LAKE ALMANOR GREBE FESTIVAL, THE PROPOSED PILOT STUDY WILL CREATE A FEW SMALL EXCLUSION ZONES WHERE THE INSTALLATION OF ARTIFICIAL NESTING PLATFORMS AND DEPLOYMENT OF SOCIAL ATTRACTION METHODS WILL HAVE MINOR IMPACTS TO EXISTING REGULATED WATER USES AND ACTIVITIES. PREVIOUS STUDIES AT SMALLER SCALE HAVE SHOWN GREAT SUCCESS WITH THESE STYLES OF NESTING PLATFORMS FOR GREBES AND OTHER DIVING BIRDS.

THIS PROJECT IS SPECIFICALLY FOR THE COMPLETE DEVELOPMENT OF THE NEW H.J. DEBAKER EAGLES NEST PARK AND BOAT LAUNCH.THE LAUNCH IS LOCATED IN BROWN COUNTY, WISCONSIN. THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IS ONE OF MANY PARTNERS SPONSORING THIS PROJECT. THE AREA WILL BECOME A PUBLIC SITE FOR RECREATIONAL BOATERS, SHORE FISHING, WILDLIFE WATCHING, AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE OUTDOOR HERITAGE OF NE WISCONSIN. ONCE COMPLETE THE SITE WILL HAVE 4 LAUNCH LANES, ACCESSIBLE BREAKWATER ACCESS, RESTROOMS, A BOAT WASH STATION, AND SEATING AREAS.

DUCKS UNLIMITED (DU) WILL PARTNER WITH THE OHIO DIVISION OF WILDLIFE (ODOW) TO PURCHASE AND PERMANENTLY PROTECT A 110-ACRE PROPERTY TO EXPAND MOXLEY WILDLIFE AREA IN ERIE COUNTY, OHIO. DU WILL BID AND CONTRACT THE DUE DILIGENCE NEEDED TO PURCHASE THIS PROPERTY FROM A WILLING SELLER AT THE APPRAISED FAIR MARKET VALUE, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TITLE SEARCH AND TITLE INSURANCE, AN APPRAISAL AND APPRAISAL REVIEW TO UNIFORM APPRAISAL STANDARDS FOR FEDERAL LAND ACQUISITION (UASFLA) STANDARDS, AND A BOUNDARY SURVEY.THE SUBJECT PROPERTY CONTAINS APPROXIMATELY 87 ACRES OF COASTAL EMERGENT MARSH, 17 ACRES OF ROAD RIGHT-OF-WAY AND 6 ACRES OF ADJACENT UPLAND FOREST. APPROXIMATELY 80 ACRES OF THE COASTAL MARSH IS PROTECTED BY A PERMANENT WETLANDS RESERVE PROGRAM (WRP) EASEMENT WITH THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE (USDA), AND IT IS CONTAINED WITHIN A LEVEE SYSTEM TO PROTECT IT FROM HIGH LAKE LEVELS AND TO FACILITATE MANAGEMENT OF THE HISTORIC COASTAL EMERGENT WETLAND. A PUMP AND WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE ARE USED TO MANIPULATE WATER LEVELS AND MANAGE VEGETATION IN THIS HIGH-QUALITY MARSH. DU WILL PURCHASE THIS PROPERTY AND TRANSFER TITLE TO ODOW TO EXPAND MOXLEY WILDLIFE AREA. ODOW EXPECTS THIS PROPERTY WILL BE OPEN TO THE PUBLIC FOR HUNTING AND OTHER RECREATIONAL USES.

DU WILL CONSTRUCT A NEW DIKE AND PROVIDE PIKE ACCESS TO THE NORTHERN SECTION OF THE MAIN IMPOUNDMENT VIA CULVERTS. INSTALLING CULVERTS WITH CARP EXCLUSION CAPABILITY WILL PROVIDE FISH ACCESS TO THE NORTHERN SECTION OF THE MAIN IMPOUNDMENT. THE IMPOUNDMENT WILL BE DESIGNED AND MANAGED TO MAXIMIZE FISH PRODUCTION BUT WILL STILL SERVE AS A HIGH-QUALITY, MODERATELY PROTECTED, WETLAND FOR ALL WILDLIFE. THE PROPOSED EFFORT WOULD ALSO IMPROVE PUBLIC ACCESS AND PROTECT PAST CONSERVATION INVESTMENTS.

THE WINNEBAGO COUNTY PARKS DEPARTMENT IS PLANNING TO IMPROVE UPON AND EXPAND THE GRUNDMAN BOAT LANDING LOCATED IN THE TOWN OF VINLAND WITHIN WINNEBAGO COUNTY. THE GRUNDMAN BOAT LANDING IS LOCATED ON THE WEST SHORE OF LAKE WINNEBAGO. CURRENTLY THE LANDING CAN ACCOMMODATE UP TO 60 BOAT TRAILERS WITH FOUR BOAT LAUNCHES.IN 2023, WINNEBAGO COUNTY IS GOING TO RECONSTRUCT THE BOAT LANDING TO ADD 60 MORE BOAT TRAILER PARKING STALLS, 3 MORE BOAT LAUNCHES, A 100  TRANSIENT DOCK, AN ADA CANOE KAYAK LAUNCH, A BATHROOM WITH RUNNING WATER, DREDGING, SITE LIGHTING, SITE SECURITY, AND ALL NEW ASPHALT PAVEMENT. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BE BUILT TO ADA REQUIREMENTS.

NEW WATER AND PARTNERS HAVE CONDUCTED FIELD INVENTORIES ALONG 16 MILES OF ASHWAUBENON CREEK AND 10 MILES OF DUTCHMAN CREEK. INFORMATION WAS COLLECTED ON SOIL TYPE, HEIGHT, AND LENGTH, PHOTOS WERE CAPTURED, AND CONDITIONS WERE NOTED SUCH AS STREAMBANK EROSION, BARRIERS TO FISH PASSAGE, AREAS OF GULLY EROSION, INVASIVE SPECIES, PIPE AND DRAINAGE OUTLETS, DUMPING SITES, ROAD AND STREAM CROSSINGS, TILE DRAIN OUTLETS, AREAS NEEDING CREEK OR DITCH CLEARING, AREAS OF EXCESSIVE SEDIMENT DEPOSITION, AND WETLANDS. THE INVENTORY RESULTS SHOW THE NEED FOR STREAMBANK STABILIZATION TO CORRECT EROSION ISSUES AND DEBRIS CLEARING TO REDUCE BARRIERS TO FISH PASSAGE AND REDUCE EROSION. STREAMBANK INSTABILITY, EROSION, AND BANK FAILURE ARE OCCURRING FROM A LACK LOSS OF HEALTHY NATURAL VEGETATION ALONG STREAMBANKS. DEVELOPMENT, MAINTENANCE ISSUES, ROW CROPPING WITHOUT BUFFERS, AND POORLY MANAGED HISTORIC LIVESTOCK GRAZING HAS CONTRIBUTED TO THE LOSS OF NATURAL RIPARIAN VEGETATION IN THE WATERSHED.OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS NEW WATER WILL ADDRESS WATER QUALITY, RIPARIAN AND INSTREAM HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, AND DEGRADED AQUATIC HABITAT BY RESTORING 1,200 1,500 FEET OF RIPARIAN CORRIDORS IN ACDC. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE IN STREAM DEBRIS REMOVAL, SELECTIVE TREE THINNING, INVASIVE PLANT REMOVAL, ADDING IN STREAM HABITAT FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE, PLANTING OF DESIRABLE TREE SPECIES, AND SEEDING THE FLOODPLAIN WITH NATIVE SEED MIX WHERE THERE IS A LACK OF QUALITY HERBACEOUS VEGETATION. RESTORING RIPARIAN CORRIDORS IN ACDC WILL IMPROVE DOWNSTREAM WATER QUALITY AND AQUATIC HABITATS BY REDUCING RUNOFF AND STABILIZING STREAM BANKS, BOTH SOURCES OF EXCESS NUTRIENTS AND SEDIMENT. ADDITIONALLY, THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT FOR FORAGE AND POLLINATOR SPECIES AND ENHANCE MIGRATORY BIRD AND WATERFOWL NESTING HABITAT.

THE UPPER FOX PRIORITY PROTECTION AREA PHASE II WILL RESULT IN THE PROTECTION AND LONG TERM PRESERVATION OF ANADDITIONAL 40 ACRES OF HABITAT. THE FOLLOWING SPECIES WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT  MANY SPECIES OFWATERFOWL INCLUDING MALLARDS, BLUE WINGED TEAL, WOOD DUCKS, CANADA GEESE  A VARIETY OF EGRETS, HERONS, ANDBITTERNS  A VARIETY OF SHOREBIRDS  SEDGE WRENS  NORTHERN HARRIERS. ONCE RESTORED THE AREAS WOULD PROVIDE IMPROVEDWILDLIFE HABITAT AND POTENTIALLY SUPPORT THE FEDERALLY THREATENED EASTERN PRAIRIE FRINGED ORCHID, WHICH IS FOUNDON SEVERAL NEARBY TRACTS OF THE WPA.THESE ACRES WILL BE OPEN TO THE PUBLIC PROVIDING A VARIETY OF OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES.THIS PROJECT WILL BE PUBLICIZED THROUGH DUCKS UNLIMITED WITH CREDIT GIVEN TO NRDA FOR THEIR CONTRIBUTION TO THEPROJECT AND WETLAND CONSERVATION. LANDS PROTECTED THROUGH THIS EFFORT WILL BE SIGNED AT PUBLIC ENTRANCE POINTSWHERE ALL PARTNERS WILL BE RECOGNIZED.

THE LAND CONSERVANCY PROPOSES TO PURCHASE A CONSERVATION EASEMENT ON APPROXIMATELY 48.018 ACRES OF THE TOTAL 52.4 ACRES OWNED BY THE JEFFERSON CONSERVATION CLUB. THE TERMS OF THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT WOULD PROHIBIT TIMBERING, FUTURE IMPACTS TO THE SURFACE FROM OIL AND  GAS EXPLORATION, AND AGRICULTURAL USES ON THE PROPERTY BUT WOULD ALLOW THE CLUB TO CONTINUE TO USE THE PROPERTY FOR PASSIVE RECREATION USES, SUCH AS HIKING, CAMPING, AND CONSERVATION OUTREACH ACTIVITIES TO THE COMMUNITY, AS WELL AS HUNTING, FISHING, AND TRAPPING, WHICH IS THE SPECIFIC INTENTION OF THE CLUB. THE LAND CONSERVANCY WOULD MONITOR THE EASEMENT ANNUALLY AND STEWARD AND DEFEND THE EASEMENT AS NECESSARY IN PERPETUITY.

OCONTO COUNTY PROPOSES TO RESTORE WETLANDS FOR FISH SPECIES TO USE DURING THEIR SPAWNING MIGRATION WHILE AT THE SAME TIME INVENTORY AND CORRECT AND IMPEDIMENTS THAT ARE FOUND. THIS PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE IN THE COASTAL WETLANDS AND TRIBUTARIES OF THE BAY OF GREEN BAY ON LAKE MICHIGAN.THE GOAL OF THE RESTORATION PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF ADULT NORTHERN PIKE IN THE BAY AND ITS TRIBUTARIES WHILE ALSO REMOVING IMPEDIMENTS IN THESE TRIBUTARIES TO BENEFIT ALL FISH SPECIES. THIS GOAL WILL BE SUCCESSFULLY ACHIEVED WITH THREE MAJOR POTENTIAL ACTIONS  1) THE CREATION, RESTORATION AND CONNECTION OF WETLANDS TO MAJOR PIKE SPAWNING ROUTES, 2) THE REMOVAL OF FISH IMPEDIMENTS SUCH AS ROCK DAMS, IMPROPERLY PLACED CULVERTS AND FARM CROSSINGS WHICH RESTRICT WATER FLOW, AND 3) THE CONTINUATION OF PIKE RESEARCH IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN GB AND SHEDD AQUARIUM.

THE BAIRD CREEK PRESERVATION FOUNDATION HAS THE OPPORTUNITY TO PURCHASE FIVE PARCELS OF LAND WITHIN THE BAIRD CREEK WATERSHED THAT WILL BOTH PROTECT THESE PARCELS FROM DEVELOPMENT AND ALLOW THE FOUNDATION TO COMMENCE RESTORATION WORK ON THE PARCELS. TWO PARCELS, HORKMAN PURCHASE, IS ADJACENT TO 34 ACRES THE FOUNDATION PURCHASED IN 2012 AND WE NOW HAVE THE CHANCE TO ADD AN ADDITIONAL 46 ACRES TO THE RESTORATION PROJECT AREA. BY ACQUIRING THIS ADDITIONAL ACREAGE, WE CAN PRESERVE AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY TO BAIRD CREEK BY PROVIDING AN ADDITIONAL NATURAL BUFFER TO THE CHANNEL OF BAIRD CREEK THAT RUNS THROUGH THE PROPERTY AND FEEDS FROM TRIBUTARIES OUT INTO HUMBOLDT AND EATON TOWNSHIP FARMLAND. THESE PARCELS WILL ALLOW FOR LARGE SCALE HABITAT RESTORATION OF WETLAND AND UPLAND PRAIRIE. FUNCTIONAL GAINS OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE AN INCREASE IN FLORISTIC INTEGRITY  CONTROL OF INVASIVE SPECIES, INCREASING NATIVE FLORISTIC DIVERSITY , STORM AND FLOOD WATER STORAGE, WATER QUALITY PROTECTION, AND WILDLIFE HABITAT  ADDITION OF HABITAT STRUCTURE, CONTIGUOUS HABITAT CORRIDORS, AND FORAGING RESOURCES . THE OTHER THREE PARCELS, GERSEK PURCHASE, WILL PROTECT THE 12.96 ACRES THAT ARE IN A PRIME AREA FOR DEVELOPMENT. IT WILL CREATE A LINK BETWEEN THE BAIRD CREEK GREENWAY AND 20 ACRES OF LANDLOCKED GREENSPACE THAT THE CITY OF GREEN BAY OWNS TO THE WEST AND WILL CREATE A CORRIDOR AND A COMMITMENT FROM THE CITY OF GREEN BAY TO ROLE THOSE WESTERN 20 ACRES INTO LONG-TERM PROTECTION BY MAKING ALL OF THE ACRES PART OF THE BAIRD CREEK GREENWAY ACREAGE. THE FOUNDATION WILL BE RESTORING STORMWATER MANAGEMENT ON THE THREE PARCELS AS WELL AS DOING RESTORATIVE WORK TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF THE FOREST AND PRAIRIE AREAS.

THE DOOR COUNTY LAND TRUST (DCLT) SEEKS TO PARTNER WITH NATURAL RESOURCES DAMAGE ASSESSMENT TRUSTEE COUNCIL FOR THE LOWER FOX RIVER GREEN BAY AREA (NRDA) TO ACQUIRE FEE TITLE TO FOUR PARCELS OF LAND, COMPRISING 22.75 ACRES, IN DOOR COUNTY, WISCONSIN. DCLT WILL IMPLEMENT THE LAND PROTECTION ACTIVITIES SPECIFIED IN THIS PROPOSAL AND PROVIDE LONG TERM MANAGEMENT. DCLT WILL WORK IN COOPERATION WITH PRIVATE DONORS TO SEEK FUNDS FOR NEARLY 75  OF THE LAND ACQUISITION COSTS TO MATCH THE  227,500.00 IN NRDA FUNDS REQUESTED. CHAMBERS ISLAND SHORELINE HABITAT PROTECTION (CICI2) WILL DIRECTLY SUPPORT A PRIMARY GOAL OF THE NRDA GRANT PROGRAM THROUGH THE LONG TERM CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF COASTAL FORESTS IN THE WESTERN LAKE MICHIGAN REGION, WHICH PROVIDE ESSENTIAL HABITAT FOR A WIDE RANGE OF FISH, MIGRATORY AND BREEDING BIRD SPECIES, AND OTHER RARE WILDLIFE AND PLANT SPECIES.

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FACILITATE ACCELERATION AND OR ENHANCE RECOVERY OF A DEGRADED DUNE SYSTEM BY RE-ESTABLISHING VEGETATION DIVERSITY AND LOCAL SCALE DUNE CONNECTIVITY AND LANDSCAPE SCALE DUNE HETEROGENEITY WHERE STORMS OR OTHER DISTURBANCES HAVE DIMINISHED VEGETATION COVER AND DIVERSITY. WILDLIFE HABITAT QUALITY WILL BE ENHANCED FOR BEACH MICE AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES DEPENDENT ON DUNE ECOSYSTEMS. RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED AT SITES DESIGNATED BY FWC ALONG THE GULF COAST AND WITHIN PERDIDO, PENSACOLA AND CHOCTAWHATCHEE-ST. ANDREW WATERSHEDS. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO DEVELOP RESTORATION PROTOCOLS, MONITOR IMPLEMENTATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF RESTORED SITES, MODIFY RESTORATION PROCEDURES AS DATA SUGGEST AND GROW AND ESTABLISH UNIQUE PLANTS TO:A. RESTORE THE HISTORICAL HETEROGENEITY OF LANDSCAPE FEATURES WITHIN THE DUNE ECOSYSTEM. B. RE-ESTABLISH CONNECTIVITY OF DUNES IN DEGRADED AREAS WHERE DISTURBANCE HAS CREATED GAPS OR OPENINGS. C. RESTORE OR ENHANCE THE NATURAL DIVERSITY AND RICHNESS OF NATIVE DUNE VEGETATION D. INCREASE THE DIVERSITY AND RESILIENCE OF THE COASTAL DUNE ECOSYSTEMS TO ENHANCE WILDLIFE BEACH MOUSE POPULATIONS THAT ARE DEPENDENT ON THEM. LARGE INVESTMENTS IN RESTORATION HAVE BEEN MADE ALONG THE GULF COAST IN THE LAST 20 YEARS. HOWEVER, VERY LITTLE INFORMATION HAS BEEN PRODUCED TO GUIDE PRACTITIONERS IN ESTABLISHING ADAPTIVE FRAMEWORKS FOR RESTORATION, BENCHMARKS, AND METRICS TO DETERMINE PROGRESS TOWARD DESIRED OUTCOMES OR TO DEVELOP CORRECTIVE ACTIONS TO MEET GOALS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT ADDRESSES KNOWLEDGE GAPS TO IMPROVE HABITAT AND SPECIES RESTORATION PLANNING AND OUTCOMES. RIGOROUS, WELL PLANNED RESTORATION MONITORING PROVIDES THE OPPORTUNITY TO EVALUATE PROGRESS TOWARDS MEETING LONG AND SHORT- TERM MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES AND AIDES THE DEVELOPMENT OF ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND DECISION MAKING FOR FUTURE RESTORATION PROJECTS. DUNE RESTORATION MONITORING ALONG THE GULF COAST HAS OFTEN BEEN SHORT TERM ( 180 DAYS) AND RESTRICTED TO  CONSTRUCTION MONITORING.  THIS PROJECT INCLUDES MONITORING OF CONSTRUCTION, PERFORMANCE, AND TO SUPPORT ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT. BEFORE RESTORATION IMPLEMENTATION, REFERENCE SITES WITHIN AND EXTERIOR TO RESTORATION SITES WILL BE IDENTIFIED, SAMPLING PROTOCOLS ESTABLISHED, AND INITIAL BASELINE DATA COLLECTED. BASELINE INFORMATION WILL INCLUDE VEGETATION COVER BY SPECIES AND ELEVATION. BASELINE INFORMATION COLLECTED PRIOR TO INSTALLATION OF RESTORATION PROJECTS WILL BE USED TO GAUGE PROGRESS TOWARDS MEETING OBJECTIVES POST RESTORATION AND TO ASSESS IF ENVIRONMENTAL AND BIOLOGICAL CHANGES THROUGH TIME RESULT FROM RESTORATION ACTIONS. BASELINE INFORMATION WILL ALSO GUIDE SITE SPECIFIC RESTORATION PLANS BASED ON CURRENT CONDITIONS. REFERENCE SITES WILL BE IDENTIFIED AS PART OF THE IDENTIFICATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF SITES FOR DUNE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES BY FWC AND FWS PERSONNEL WITH INPUT FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA. INTERNAL REFERENCE SITES WILL NOT UNDERGO ANY RESTORATION ACTIVITIES INITIALLY BUT WILL BE SIMILAR IN PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDING LEVEL OF DEGRADATION AND SPECIES COMPOSITION AND ABUNDANCE TO SITES THAT WILL BE RESTORED. ASSESSING DIFFERENCES IN VEGETATION COMPOSITION AND COVER AND SAND ACCUMULATION BETWEEN INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL REFERENCE SITES AND RESTORED SITES WILL QUANTIFY THE EFFECTIVENESS OF RESTORATION ACTIVITIES. EXTERNAL REFERENCE SITES WILL REPRESENT THE PHYSICAL AND BIOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS THAT ARE THE GOAL OF THE RESTORATION PROJECT AND WILL PROVIDE BENCHMARKS TO ASSESS THE LEVEL OF PROGRESS MADE THROUGH TIME AFTER RESTORATION. EXTERIOR REFERENCE SITES SELECTED WILL BE SOMEWHAT PHYSICALLY AND BIOLOGICALLY LIKE SITES TO BE RESTORED BUT WILL NOT BE DEGRADED. REFERENCES SITES PROVIDE A CHECK TO SEPARATE THE EFFECTS OF NATURAL DISTURBANCE FROM AN APPARENT LACK OF PROGRESS ASSOCIATED WITH RESTORATION. VEGETATION MONITORING WILL BE SUPERVISED BY PERSONNEL FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA.

THE VILLAGE OF SOLVAYS GOAL IS TO MITIGATE THE LOSS OF TREES ALONG THE ERIE CANAL RECREATIONAL TRAIL ADJACENT TO BELLE ISLE ROAD WITH THE PLANTING OF NEW TREES IN THE CORRIDOR. THE FIRST PHASE OF THE TREE PLANTING PROJECT HAS BEEN IMPLEMENTED AND 44 TREES HAVE BEEN PLANTED. THE VILLAGE OF SOLVAY IS APPLYING FOR THE SECOND PHASE OF THE TREE PLANTING PROJECT AND WILL PLANT AN ADDITIONAL 56 TREES ALONG THE TRAIL TO THE INTERSECTION OF BELLE ISLE ROAD AND MATHEWS AVENUE.  AWARD PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE PREFERRED RESTORATION ALTERNATIVE OF HABITAT ENHANCEMENT AND ENHANCEMENT OF PUBLIC RECREATIONAL USE (AS DESCRIBED IN THE 2017 ONONDAGA LAKE NATURAL RESOURCE DAMAGE ASSESSMENT RESTORATION PLAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT).  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE: PLANTING 56 TREES ALONG THE ERIE CANAL RECREATIONAL TRAIL ADJACENT TO BELLE ISLE ROAD TO THE INTERSECTION OF BELLE ISLE ROAD AND MATHEWS AVENUE (U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WILL BE INVOLVED WITH REVIEW AND APPROVAL OF THE DESIGN AND TREES SPECIES  PROVIDE GUIDANCE AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT  AND IMMEDIATELY HALT AN ACTIVITY IF PERFORMANCE SPECIFICATIONS ARE NOT MET), WATERING, MAINTENANCE, AND MONITORING.  DELIVERABLES INCLUDE: PLANTING OF TREES AND DOCUMENTATION OF COMPLETED HABITAT AND PUBLIC USE ENHANCEMENTS.   EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: 1) IMPROVEMENT AND RESTORATION OF THE HEALTH OF THE ONONDAGA LAKE WATERSHED  2) PRESERVATION OF NATURAL AREAS AND RESTORATION OF HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE  AND 3) RECREATIONAL ENHANCEMENTS TO THE ONONDAGA LAKE WATERSHED.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ON THE PROJECT INCLUDE THE PUBLIC AND THE NATURAL RESOURCES WITHIN THE ONONDAGA LAKE WATERSHED.

THE RUTGERS ECOLOGICAL PRESERVE IS LOCATED ADJACENT TO THE RUTGERS UNIVERSITY S LIVINGSTON CAMPUS IN NEW BRUNSWICK, MIDDLESEX COUNTY, NEW JERSEY. THE PROPOSED RECREATIONAL RESTORATION PROJECT INCLUDES: THE CONSTRUCTION OF AN ADA ACCESSIBLE LOOP TRAIL AT TEH RUTGERS ECOLOGICAL PRESERVE THAT RUNS THROUGH MATURE FOREST AND PROVIDES CLOSE-UP VIEWS OF BUELL BROOK  RESURFACING THE TRAIL LOOP WITH FINE, COMPACTED GRAVEL  AND THE CONSTRUCTION OF A LEVEL-PULLOUT AND BENCH NEAR BUELL BROOK. THE PULLOUT WILL ALLOW ACCESS TO A SHALLOW SECTION OF BUELL BROOK SO VISITORS HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO EXPLORE THE STREAM IN A SAFE MANNER. RUTGERS UNIVERSITY STUDENTS WILL DEVELOP A SERIES OF EDUCATIONAL SIGNAGE TO INSTALL ALONG THE TRAIL AND HIGHLIGHT THE AREA S NATURAL AND CULTURAL HISTORY. THE TRAIL WILL BE OPEN TO RUTGERS UNIVERSITY S STUDENTS, FACULTY, AND STAFF, AS WELL AS THE BROADER COMMUNITY.

THIS 3 YEAR PROJECT WILL ACHIEVE TWO OVERARCHING TASKS. FIRST, IT WILL CONDUCT 2 SEASONS OF SEABIRD VESSEL SURVEYS, INCLUDING RECRUITING, TRAINING, CERTIFYING, AND SUPERVISING MARINE BIRD OBSERVERS FOR UP TO 60 DAYS OF SURVEYS ANNUALLY DURING CALENDAR YEARS 2023 AND 2024 IN THE NORTHERN GULF OF MEXICO (GOM) ON NOAA SHIPS AND ALONGSIDE MARINE MAMMAL OBSERVERS. SECOND, IT WILL DESIGN AN INTEGRATED SYSTEM CAPABLE OF STORAGE, RETRIEVAL, AND ANALYSIS FUNCTIONS FOR KEY DATA COLLECTED ON GOM MARINE BIRDS FOR LONG TERM CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT, BOTH FROM THIS AND RELATED PROJECTS

THE BUFFALO NIAGARA RIVER LAND TRUST PROPOSAL INCLUDES THE STEWARDSHIP OF CITY OF BUFFALO PROPERTIES, APPROXIMATELY 28.10 ACRES ON THE NORTH BANK OF THE BUFFALO RIVER IN THE CITY OF BUFFALO, ERIE COUNTY, NEW YORK.  AWARD PURPOSE  U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, THE TUSCARORA NATION, AND NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION SETTLED THE BUFFALO RIVER NATURAL RESOURCE DAMAGE ASSESSMENT CASE IN 2022, WITH THE FINAL CONSENT DECREE ENTERED BY THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT ON FEBRUARY 22, 2022. PURSUANT TO THE CONSENT DECREE, SECTION VIII, PARAGRAPH 18(B), HONEYWELL SHALL ARRANGE FOR THE RECORDING OF THE APPLICABLE CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND RESTRICTION, IN THE FORM ATTACHED AS APPENDIX E TO THE CONSENT DECREE, FOR CITY OF BUFFALO, NY PROPERTIES  HOUGHTON PARK AND EACH OF THE UPSTREAM PARCELS. THE TRUSTEES (THIRD PARTY ENFORCERS), BUFFALO NIAGARA RIVER LAND TRUST (GRANTEE), AND THE CITY OF BUFFALO (GRANTOR) AGREED TO THE FORM OF THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND RESTRICTION ATTACHED IN APPENDIX E OF THE CONSENT DECREE. PURSUANT TO APPENDIX E 1 AND E 2 OF THE CONSENT DECREE, PARAGRAPH 7, THE TRUSTEES SHALL PAY TO THE BUFFALO NIAGARA RIVER LAND TRUST A ONE TIME PAYMENT IN THE AMOUNT OF  2,495.00 PER ACRE MULTIPLIED BY THE ACREAGE OF THE CITY OF BUFFALO PROTECTED PROPERTIES (28.10 ACRES) FOR A TOTAL OF  70,110. THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND RESTRICTIONS ARE TO ENSURE THAT THE PROPERTIES WILL BE MANAGED, IN PERPETUITY, IN A MANNER CONSISTENT WITH THE CONSENT DECREE RESTORATION PLAN INTENDED USES (OBJECTIVES) BASED ON LAND USE RESPONSIBILITIES AND RESTRICTIONS SET FORTH WITHIN THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND RESTRICTIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ASSURANCE THAT APPROPRIATE LAND USES TO THE PROTECTED PROPERTIES WILL BE RETAINED FOREVER PREDOMINANTLY IN ITS OPEN AND NATURAL CONDITION, TO PROTECT THE NATURAL HABITAT LOCATED ON THE PROTECTED PROPERTY IN PERPETUITY FOR BIRDS, FISH, WILDLIFE, AND HUMAN USE, INCLUDING PROTECTING WETLANDS, UPLANDS, AND STREAM HABITAT, PROTECTING FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT AND THE ECOLOGICAL VALUE OF THE LAND, PROVIDING OPEN SPACE PROTECTION, PROTECTING SCENIC AND NATURAL FEATURES AND ALLOWING COMPATIBLE OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL AND EDUCATIONAL USES.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED AS PART OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE  LONG TERM STEWARDSHIP, MONITORING FOR PROHIBITED USES, MANAGEMENT OF  HABITAT, PASSIVE PUBLIC USE, PLANTS, FACILITIES AND STRUCTURES, SIGNAGE, CONDUCTING INSPECTIONS, AND NOTIFICATION TO THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION. BUFFALO NIAGARA RIVER LAND TRUST WILL HOLD THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND RESTRICTIONS TO PROTECT THE CITY OF BUFFALO PROPERTIES IMPORTANT TO THE CONSERVATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES. BUFFALO NIAGARA RIVER LAND TRUST WILL CONDUCT SEMI ANNUAL SITE MONITORING VISITS, USE BEST EFFORTS TO REMOVE LITTER, REPORT TO TRUSTEES ANY CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND RESTRICTION VIOLATIONS, AND ANNUALLY PROVIDE A ONE PAGE REPORT TO THE TRUSTEES. U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WILL PROVIDE WRITTEN RESPONSE (APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL) TO REQUESTS FOR USE THE STEWARDSHIP FUNDS BEYOND THE USES IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND RESTRICTIONS, REVIEW AND APPROVE OF THE AFFIRMATIVE RIGHTS INCLUDING THE RIGHT TO ERECT SIGNS, GATES, AND FENCES, AND WILL TAKE ANY AND ALL ACTIONS WITH RESPECT TO THE PROTECTED PROPERTY AS MAY BE NECESSARY OR APPROPRIATE,TO ENFORCE AND REMEDY OR ABATE VIOLATIONS OF THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND RESTRICTIONS.  DELIVERABLES INCLUDE  ANNUAL INSPECTIONS REPORTS, PHOTOGRAPHIC DOCUMENTATION OF CITY OF BUFFALO PROPERTIES.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE  1) PRESERVATION AND IMPROVEMENT OF HABITAT ADJACENT TO THE BUFFALO RIVER  AND 2) PROTECTION AND ENHANCEMENT OF PUBLIC ACCESS TO, AND USE, INCLUDING RECREATION, OF NATURAL AREAS ADJACENT TO THE BUFFALO RIVER   INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ON THE PROJECT INCLUDE THE PUBLIC AND THE NATURAL RESOURCES ADJACENT TO THE BUFFALO RIVER.

THE SHIPYARD PROMISES TO BE A PROMINENT DESTINATION WITHIN THE UPPER MIDWEST. ONCE A CENTER FOR RAIL AND WATER TRANSPORT OF RAW MATERIALS, THE NOW VACATED BROWNFIELD WILL BE DRAMATICALLY TRANSFORMED INTO A DESTINATION OF RECREATION AND TOURISM. NRDA GRANT FUNDS WILL BE USED TO CONSTRUCT AN ELEVATED FISHING WHARF OVER THE FOX RIVER, AND TO PROVIDE HABITAT ENHANCEMENTS. SPECIFIC IMPROVEMENTS INCLUDE INSTALLATION OF ANCHORED LOG COVER STRUCTURES, NATIVE RIPARIAN BUFFER EXPANSION AND STABILIZATION, AND INSTALLATION OF A FLOATING ISLAND.

THE MEMORIAL PARK SITE WILL PROVIDE IMPROVED BOATING AND FISHING ACCESS TO AN ISOLATED AREA OF DUCK CREEK BY CONSTRUCTING AN ELEVATED BOARDWALK AND USING EXISTING PATHS TO ACCESS THE WATER'S EDGE. THE PROJECT INCLUDES RELOCATING A PREVIOUSLY USED STEEL BRIDGE TO THE SITE TO PROVIDE ACCESS OVER A SMALL DRAINAGE WAY. REMOVABLE DOCKS WILL BE PROVIDED ON THE RIVER FOR BOAT AND FISHING ACCESS. NEARBY PARKING LOT IMPROVEMENTS AND SIGNAGE WILL BE INSTALLED. WORK WILL BE COMPLETED BY VILLAGE STAFF AND EQUIPMENT, AND WILL INCLUDE EROSION CONTROL, TREE AND BRUSH CLEARING, CONSTRUCTION OF BRIDGE SUPPORT PILINGS, CONSTRUCTION OF THE BOARDWALK, INSTALLATION AND REMOVAL OF DOCKS, TRASH REMOVAL AND MAINTENANCE OF THE BOARDWALK AND DOCKS. IT IS EXPECTED THAT MORE PEOPLE WILL BE ABLE TO ACCESS DUCK CREEK FOR FISHING FROM THIS LOCATION. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO PROVIDE A LOCATION FOR SMALL BOATS SUCH AS KAYAKS AND CANOES TO LAUNCH OR REST, AND SIGHTSEERS, HIKERS, AND BIRD WATCHERS TO EXPLORE.THE WEST DEERFIELD DRIVE SITE WILL PROVIDE SAFE CANOE AND KAYAK ACCESS TO DUCK CREEK AND LOWER GREEN BAY BY ADDING A NEW KAYAK LAUNCH. THE PROJECT INCLUDES RECONSTRUCTING A PORTION OF EXISTING BOARDWALK TO PROVIDE SAFE ACCESS FROM THE ROADWAY. THE KAYAK LAUNCH PLATFORM WILL BE PROVIDED FOR BOAT AND FISHING ACCESS. NEARBY ROAD STRIPING AND SIGNAGE WILL BE INSTALLED. WORK WILL BE COMPLETED BY VILLAGE STAFF AND EQUIPMENT, AND WILL INCLUDE EROSION CONTROL, BRUSH CLEARING, CONSTRUCTION OF A NEW PORTION OF BOARDWALK AND RECONSTRUCTION OF AN EXISTING PORTION OF BOARDWALK, POST INSTALLATION FOR STIFF-ARMS, TRASH REMOVAL, AND MAINTENANCE OF THE BOARDWALK LAUNCH EQUIPMENT. IT IS EXPECTED THAT MORE PEOPLE WILL BE ABLE TO ACCESS DUCK CREEK FROM THIS LOCATION BECAUSE OF THE EASE OF ACCESS, AND IT WILL PROMOTE WATER RECREATION, EXPAND FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, BIRD WATCHING AND CULTURAL ACCESS IN A RELATIVELY UNDISTURBED AND VALUABLE SECTION OF WATERWAY.

THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE AND ENHANCE PUBLIC ACCESS FROM THE METRO BOAT LAUNCH TO FISHERIES IN THE LOWER FOX RIVER AND BAY OF GREEN BAY. CURRENTLY, ACCESS FROM THIS FACILITY TO THE FISHERIES IS VERY LIMITED. THE EXISTING BOAT LAUNCH DOCKING SYSTEM IS IN VERY POOR CONDITION AND IS NOT DESIGNED FOR USE DURING HIGHWATER CONDITIONS WHICH HAS MADE ACCESS TO THE DOCKS VERY DIFFICULT. PORTIONS OF THE DOCK SYSTEM HAVE BEEN TIED TOGETHER TO HELP ACCOMMODATE RECENT HIGHWATER LEVELS. OVER THE LAST COUPLE OF YEARS, WE HAVE HAD TO COMPLETELY REMOVE 3 OF THE DOCKS FROM THE LAUNCH AREA BECAUSE THEY ARE NOT FIT FOR USE. PIECES OF THE REMOVED DOCKS HAVE BEEN USED TO REPAIR THE REMAINING 2 DOCKS. THE CURRENT HIGHWATER CONDITIONS HAVE ALSO CAUSED DETERIORATION OF THE BOAT RAMP PAVEMENT RENDERING PORTIONS OF THE RAMPS UNUSABLE. ADDITIONALLY, THERE ARE NO DESIGNATED LAND-BASED FISHING OPPORTUNITIES AT THIS SITE. PATRONS HAVE EXPRESSED THEIR DISPLEASURE WITH THE CURRENT FACILITIES AND ARE ASKING THE CITY TO FIX THE LAUNCH.THIS PROJECT WILL REPLACE THE BOAT LAUNCH DOCK AND RAMP SYSTEM ALLOWING FOR FULL USE AND ACCESS BY ACCOMMODATING ORDINARY LOW AND HIGHWATER CONDITIONS. ADDITIONALLY, A SHORELINE FISHING AREA WILL BE CONSTRUCTED ALONG THE EXISTING SEAWALL TO THE NORTH OF THE BOAT LAUNCH. THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL PROVIDE 5 DOCKS AND 10 LAUNCH LANES FOR PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE LOWER FOX RIVER AND BAY OF GREEN BAY AND AN ADA ACCESSIBLE LAND-BASED FISHING AREA.

THE PURCHASE AND INSTALLATION OF A KAYAK LAUNCH FOR WILL BE A GREAT ADDITION TO THE SHORELINE OF CITY OF STURGEON BAY. THIS WILL BE THE WESTERNMOST FACILITY OF THIS TYPE IN THE BAY OF STURGEON BAY WHICH WILL PROVIDE PEOPLE OF ALL ABILITIES ACCESS TO THE WESTERN PART OF STURGEON BAY. THE LOCATION OF THE LAUNCH WAS PICKED FOR A FEW REASONS. IT GIVES ACCESS TO AN AREA WHERE FEW KAYAKS VENTURE DUE TO THE LACK OF FACILITIES. THE SHORELINE WILL REQUIRE ONLY MINIMAL WORK TO PREPARE FOR THE INSTALLATION. THERE IS ALREADY A SMALL PARKING AREA TO ALLOW FOR OFF-STREET PARKING.

THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT COSTS PROJECT IS A PREFERRED ALTERNATIVE RESTORATION PROJECT WITHIN THE 2016 RICHARDSON HILL ROAD SUPERFUND SITE FINAL RESTORATION PLAN THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT COST RESTORATION PROJECT COMPENSATES FOR ECOLOGICAL LOSSES DUE TO CONTAMINATION FROM THE SUPERFUND SITE AND WILL PROTECT STREAM, WETLAND, AND UPLAND HABITAT THAT MAY OTHERWISE BE DEVELOPED THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS THE PLACEMENT OF A PERPETUAL CONSERVATION EASEMENT ON THE PROPERTY  THE EASEMENT WILL SUBSTANTIALLY LIMIT SUBDIVISION AND RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT AND PROTECT OR CONSERVE  FOREST RESOURCES, WILDLIFE HABITAT, WATER RESOURCES, AND SCENIC RESOURCES  OTSEGO LAND TRUST CREATES A BASELINE DOCUMENTATION REPORT THAT MEMORIALIZES THE CONDITIONS OF THE PROPERTY WHEN THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT IS CLOSED  OTSEGO LAND TRUST MONITORS ALL OF ITS CONSERVATION EASEMENT PROPERTIES ON AN ANNUAL BASIS TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH THE TERMS OF THE EASEMENT  IF NECESSARY, OTSEGO LAND TRUST WILL DEFEND THE CONSERVATION EASEMENT OTSEGO LAND TRUST WILL UTILIZE THE FUNDING FOR THE REQUIRED STEWARDSHIP AND LEGAL DEFENSE CONTRIBUTION  THE DELIVERABLES SHALL BE AN EXECUTED PERPETUAL CONSERVATION EASEMENT AND A BASELINE DOCUMENTATION REPORT

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO RESTORE AND/OR ENHANCE OVER 500 ACRES OF WETLAND AND ASSOCIATED UPLAND AT FOUR PRIORITY SITES IN THE FOX RIVER-GREEN BAY FOCUS AREA. SITES INCLUDE KEN EUERS PHASE II (19ACRES), UIHLEIN WPA-DAVIS (155 ACRES), UIHLEIN WPA-WAUKAU POOL (330 ACRES), AND BOHN BERLIN (24 ACRES). THIS PROPOSAL BUILDS OFF OF THE VERY SUCCESSFUL FIRST PHASE OF THIS WORK WHICH LEVERAGED NRDA DOLLARS TO OVER ACHIEVE ON GOALS OF THAT EFFORT. IT ALSO BUILD OFF OF LAND ACQUISITION EFFORTS OF NRDA IN MOVING INTO THE RESTORATION PHASE OF DAVIS AND BOHN-BERLIN WHICH WERE BOTH PROTECTED USING NRDA FUNDS IN COMBINATION WITH OTHER SOURCES. PROJECTS RANGE FROM CONVERSION OF AGRICULTURAL LAND TO WETLANDS AND GRASSLANDS USING DITCH PLUGS AND SMALL BERMSCOMBINED WITH NATIVE PRAIRIE PLANTINGS (DAVIS AND BOHN-BERLIN) TO FLOWAGE RENOVATIONS BYREPAIRING AND RESHAPING BERMS AND ADDING WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES (KEN EUERS II, WAUKAU POOL).ALL OF THESE GREATLY ENHANCE THE WILDLIFE VALUES WHILE ALSO PROVIDING SIGNIFICANT WATER QUALITY BENEFITS.

THIS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT SHALL PROVIDE FOR PUBLIC SHORELINE FISHING ACCESS (AMERICAN'S WITH DISABILITY ACT DOCK, PARKING, ACAND CESSIBILITY) TO THE OCONTO RIVER. IN ADDITION, 1,000 FEET OF ERODING OCONTO RIVER SHORELINE WILL BE REPAIRED AND PROTECTED IN ORDER TO IMPROVE SAFETY FOR PUBLIC USERS ALONG THIS HIGHLY DESIRED FISHINGAREA. THE INTENT IS TO UTILIZE 8" - 18" ROCK AS THIS HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE THE PREFERRED SPAWNING SUBSTRATE FOR FISH/PREY SPECIES IN THE AREA, WITH A PARTICULAR FOCUS ONSMALLMOUTH BASS.

THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO RETURN SAFE, EFFICIENT, AND RELIABLE ACCESS TO SUBSISTENCE RESOURCES TO THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF PORT GRAHAM BY RESTORING PREVIOUSLY PASSABLE LOGGING ROADS AND PROTECTING HABITAT OF IMPORTANT SUBSISTENCE SPECIES  THIS GOAL IS A MUTUAL PRIORITY OF THE PORT GRAHAM CORPORATION  PGC , NATIVE VILLAGE OF PORT GRAHAM  NVPG , CHUGACHMIUT, AND THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  THE ROCKY LAKE ROAD CONSISTS OF 26 MILES OF AN ALL SEASON, PERMANENT ROAD ORIGINALLY BUILT AS A HAUL ROAD FOR LOGGING VEHICLES BETWEEN THE COMMUNITY OF PORT GRAHAM AND ROCKY LAKE  THE ROAD CONDITION HAS DETERIORATED IN NUMEROUS LOCATIONS DUE TO FAILED RIVER CROSSINGS AND VEGETATION OVERGROWTH MAKING IT IMPASSABLE  NO COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATION IS AVAILABLE RELATED TO THE CONDITION OF THE ROCKY LAKE ROAD, HENCE THE NEED FOR GATHERING ADDITIONAL DATA PROJECT PARTNERS INCLUDING PORT GRAHAM CORPORATION, NATIVE VILLAGE OF PORT GRAHAM, CHUGACHMIUT, AND THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  PROPOSE A HOLISTIC APPROACH THAT INCLUDES AN INVENTORY AND CONDITION ASSESSMENT OF ROCKY LAKE ROAD, ROAD CLEARING, IMPROVING THE EXISTING ROAD, AND CONSTRUCTING SAFE STREAM CROSSINGS NEEDED TO ACCESS SUBSISTENCE RESOURCES AND PROVIDE FUTURE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES IN FY22 THE PARTNERSHIP WILL FOCUS ON INVENTORY, ASSESSMENT, DESIGN, PLANNING AND ACCESS TO INITIAL PRIORITY CONSTRUCTION SITES  THE PARTNERSHIP WILL COMPLETE A FIELD INVENTORY AS AN INITIAL STEP THAT WILL RESULT IN A THOROUGH ANALYSIS OF THE ROCKY LAKE ROAD INCLUDING DETAILED INFORMATION ABOUT THE EXISTING ROAD SYSTEM, SUBSISTENCE ACCESS NEEDS, AND UPDATED INFORMATION ABOUT THE PHYSICAL AND BIOLOGICAL CONDITIONS ASSOCIATED WITH THE ROAD SYSTEM  BASED ON FINDINGS ABOUT THE ROAD, COMMUNITY NEEDS, AND BIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENTS THE ROCKY ROAD PARTNERSHIP WILL DEVELOP A 4 YEAR ROAD REMEDIATION AND HABITAT RESTORATION PLAN TO ACHIEVE PARTNERSHIP GOALS

THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS  PIS  AND DOI ECONOMISTS HAVE REFINED THE OFFICE OF RESTORATION AND DAMAGE ASSESSMENT  ORDA  FUNDED MUSSEL REA DEVELOPED FOR THE CLINCH RIVER LONE MOUNTAIN RESTORATION REPORT IN SUPPORT OF A LARGE PCB CASE  THROUGH THAT PROCESS, RESEARCH QUESTIONS HAVE ARISEN  E G , BASELINE DETERMINATION, SENSITIVITY OF THE FECUNDITY RATE, INCLUSION OF FUTURE GENERATIONS  AND IT HAS BECOME CLEAR THAT TRUSTEES NEED A STANDARDIZED REA MODEL THAT IS PEER REVIEWED AND PUBLISHED FOR USE IN CASE DEVELOPMENT CONCERNING INJURY TO FRESHWATER MUSSELS  IN CONTRAST WITH THE ORIGINAL CLINCH RIVER LONE MOUNTAIN RESTORATION REPORT FOR THE ORDA, A STANDARDIZED MODEL WILL BENEFIT NRDAR PRACTITIONERS BY EXPLICITLY STATING THE BIOLOGICAL AND DEMOGRAPHIC ASSUMPTIONS OF MUSSELS AND BY SIMPLIFYING THE REA PROCESS, AND WILL CARRY THE WEIGHT OF A PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION IN NRDAR CASE NEGOTIATIONS  GIVEN THE AGGRESSIVE TIMELINE TO PUBLICATION, THIS MODEL WILL FULLY EXPLORE THE LOSSES, BUT THE SCALING WILL FOCUS ON MUSSEL PROPAGATION AND REINTRODUCTION  HOWEVER, IT WILL BE FLEXIBLE ENOUGH TO ALLOW DOI ECONOMISTS TO EVALUATE ANY TYPE OF RESTORATION PROJECT ALTERNATIVE THAT LEADS TO AN UPLIFT IN THE NUMBER OF MUSSELS  AT THE REQUEST OF THE ORDA, WE WILL BE SEEKING TO PUBLISH OUR WORK IN A TOP TIER SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL  E G , JOURNAL OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT, RESTORATION ECOLOGY   WE RECOGNIZE THERE ARE CONCERNS ABOUT THE AVAILABILITY OF PRODUCTION FACILITIES NEAR INJURED AREAS, WHICH AFFECT THE FEASIBILITY, SCALE, AND COST OF POTENTIAL RESTORATION ACTIONS  SUCH ISSUES ARE VERY SITE SPECIFIC AND OUTSIDE THE EXPLICIT SCOPE OF DEVELOPING A GENERIC REA, WHICH IS PRIMARILY A WAY OF ESTIMATING INJURY AND THE REQUIRED AMOUNT OF RESTORATION  HOWEVER, WE WILL ADVISE THAT ANY RESTORATION PLANS RELYING ON THE REA SHOULD BE REALISTIC GIVEN CASE SPECIFIC CONSTRAINTS SUCH AS AVAILABILITY OF NEARBY PRODUCTION FACILITIES, AVAILABILITY OF SOURCE POPULATIONS, HABITAT AVAILABILITY FOR REINTRODUCTION  E G , SMALL VS  LARGE RIVERS , INCREASING COSTS  E G , INFLATION  FOR LONG TERM RESTORATION PROGRAMS, POTENTIAL EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON RESTORATION AREAS, AND OTHER SCENARIOS  THESE ISSUES WILL BE DISCUSSED IN THE RESULTING PUBLICATION AS FACTORS TO BE CONSIDERED WHEN USING THE REA FOR INJURY QUANTIFICATION, RESTORATION SCALING AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE RESULTING RESTORATION PLANS  THE FINAL REA WILL ALLOW FOR A RANGE OF POTENTIAL RESTORATION PLANNING OPTIONS, MAKING IT USEFUL FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF MUSSEL NRDAR CASE SITUATIONS  IT WILL ALSO BE FLEXIBLE ENOUGH FOR DOI ECONOMISTS TO ADD SCALING OPPORTUNITIES AS OUR UNDERSTANDING OF MUSSEL RESTORATION CONTINUES TO EVOLVE  ACCOMPLISHMENT OF THESE TWO OBJECTIVES WILL PROVIDE THE SERVICE S EYAK LAKE LIES WITHIN THE COMMUNITY OF CORDOVA, ALASKA. THE WATERSHED SUPPORTS SOCKEYE, PINK AND COHO SALMON, CUTTHROAT TROUT AND DOLLY VARDEN WHICH SUPPORT COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES OF LOCAL AND INTERNATIONAL SIGNIFICANCE. THE EYAK LAKE OUTLET CONTROL STRUCTURE, OR "WEIR," WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1972 TO MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF THE 1964 "GOOD FRIDAY" EARTHQUAKE. THE EARTHQUAKE CAUSED A LAKE LEVEL DROP OF UP TO 8 FEET, REDUCING SALMON SPAWNING HABITAT, MUNICIPAL WATER SUPPLIES AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THE EXISTING STRUCTURE HAS OUTLIVED ITS LIFESPAN. THE SHEET PILING WEIR IS BENT AND DISTENDED FROM THE FORCE OF UPSTREAM WATER, ICE ACTION, AND TIME. RIP RAP HAS BEEN PLACED DOWNSTREAM TO HOLD THE STRUCTURE IN PLACE AS A STOP GAP MEASURE. A "BOAT SLOT" INTENDED FOR RECREATIONAL VESSEL NAVIGATION HAS BECOME DIFFICULT AND UNSAFE TO USE DUE TO ANGLED SHEET PILING, EXPOSED TIMBERS AND UNSTABLE HYDRAULICS. THIS SLOT ALSO PROVIDED LIMITED UPSTREAM FISH PASSAGE. THE WEIR IS CURRENTLY A SEASONAL FISH BARRIER.THE PROPOSED PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE THE EXISTING OUTLET STRUCTURE TO MAINTAIN LAKE LEVELS AND ASSOCIATED BENEFITS: NEAR-SHORE SPAWNING HABITAT AND ACCESS TO UPSTREAM TRIBUTARIES, FULL POOL FOR MUNICIPAL WATER USE AND RECREATION, HYDROLOGIC CONNECTIVITY FOR WETLAND HEALTH ETC. A ROCK RAMP WILL PROVIDE GRADE CONTROL AND UPSTREAM FISH PASSAGE FOR ALL LIFESTAGES OF THE FIVE SALOMONIDS PRESENT. AND FINALLY, A SAFE AND EASILY ACCESSIBLE BOATER SLOT WILL BE INCORPORATED.

THIS PROJECT CONSISTS OF INSTALLATION OF A KAYAK/CANOE ACCESS RAMP AND ACCESSIBLE FLOATING KAYAK/CANOE DOCK IN THE CITY OF SYRACUSE INNER HARBOR TO PROVIDE AND RESTORE LOCAL WATERWAY RECREATIONAL BENEFITS TO CITY AND COUNTY RESIDENTS, INCLUDING LOCAL YOUTH AND AREA VISITORS. THE SYRACUSE INNER HARBOR IS UNDERGOINGREDEVELOPMENT AS A NEW WATERFRONT NEIGHBORHOOD IN THE CITY. RESIDENTS AND VISITORS ALIKE TO THE INNER HARBOR WILL GREATLY BENEFIT FROM PERSONAL WATERCRAFT ACCESS TO THE CREEK.THIS PROJECT MEETS THE NRDAR ONONDAGA LAKE RESTORATION SELECTION CRITERIA AS THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN INNER HARBOR KAYAK/CANOE LAUNCH PROMOTES AND INCREASES THE UTILIZATION OF ONONDAGA CREEK NATURAL RESOURCES FOR RECREATIONAL BENEFITS THAT ARE NOT CURRENTLY AVAILABLE.THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) WILL PROVIDE 90% OF FUNDING FOR THE LAUNCH CONSTRUCTION AND DOCK ACQUISITION AND INSTALLATION; REVIEW AND APPROVE THE DESIGN FOR THE LAUNCH RAMP AND DOCK INSTALLATION LOCATION; PROVIDE GUIDANCE AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT. LOCAL FUNDING WILL COMPRISE 10% OF THE PROJECT COST.

BIG CHARITY ISLAND IS LOCATED IN SAGINAW BAY OF LAKE HURON. MORE THAN 80% OF THE ISLAND IS PART OF THE MICHIGAN ISLANDS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, MANAGED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE SHIAWASSE REFUGE. BIG CHARITY ISLAND PROVIDES IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY BIRDS, REPTILES AND AMPHIBIANS AND A VARIETY OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO CONTINUE A SUCCESSFUL COLLABORATION BETWEEN FEDERAL, STATE AND NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS WORKING TOGETHER TO ADDRESS INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES THREATENING THE SENSITIVE COASTAL HABITATS, PROTECT AND ENHANCE THE RESIDENT PITCHER'S THISTLE (CIRSIUM PITCHERI) POPULATION, IMPROVE INFRASTRUCTURE ON THE ISLAND AND EDUCATE AND ENGAGE THE LOCAL COMMUNITY IN ECOLOGICAL CONSERVATION EFFORTS.

THE CENTRAL NEW YORK LAND TRUST PROPOSAL INCLUDES THE ACQUISITION, RESTORATION, AND STEWARDSHIP OF THE PLEASANT VALLEY PARCEL, AN APPROXIMATELY 203 ACRE PARCEL WITH 0.5 MILES OF ROAD FRONTAGE.- AWARD PURPOSE: THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE PREFERRED RESTORATION ALTERNATIVE OF LAND PRESERVATION, HABITAT ENHANCEMENT, AND ENHANCEMENT OF PUBLIC RECREATIONAL USE (AS DESCRIBED IN THE 2017 ONONDAGA LAKE NATURAL RESOURCE DAMAGE ASSESSMENT RESTORATION PLAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT).- ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE: ACQUISITION OF THE 203 ACRE PARCEL, LONG-TERM STEWARDSHIP OF THE PARCEL, PUBLIC USE ACCESS ENHANCEMENT (TRAILS, TRAIL MARKERS, KIOSKS, AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT ACCESSIBLE PARKING AREA AND TRAIL), PUBLIC FISHING AND YOUTH FISHING PROGRAM, HABITAT ENHANCEMENTS (U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WILL BE INVOLVED WITH HABITAT RESTORATION INCLUDING DESIGN DEVELOPMENT, DESIGN REVIEW/APPROVAL AND RESTORATION IMPLEMENTATION OVERSIGHT AND APPROVAL), MONITORING OF HABITAT AND PUBLIC USE ENHANCEMENTS, DEED RESTRICTIONS ON THE PARCELS.- DELIVERABLES INCLUDE: 1) COPY OF DEED WITH RESTRICTION, ANNUAL REPORTS THROUGH 2026, STEWARDSHIP PLAN, DOCUMENTATION OF COMPLETED: PUBIC USE ENHANCEMENTS, PUBLIC FISHING AND YOUTH FISHING PROGRAM, AND HABITAT ENHANCEMENTS.- EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: 1) IMPROVEMENT AND RESTORATION THE HEALTH OF ONONDAGA LAKE AND ITS WATERSHED; 2) PROTECTION, PRESERVATION AND ENHANCEMENT PUBLIC ACCESS TO, AND USE, INCLUDING RECREATION, OF ONONDAGA LAKE AND ITS WATERWAYS; 3) PRESERVATION OF NATURAL AREAS AND RESTORATION OF HABITATS FOR NATIVE PLANTS, AMPHIBIANS, FISH AND WILDLIFE; 4) RECREATIONAL ENHANCEMENTS TO THE ONONDAGA LAKE WATERSHED, AND 5) EDUCATION TO PEOPLE ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF ONONDAGA LAKE, ITS WATERSHED AND ITS RESOURCES.- INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ON THE PROJECT INCLUDE THE PUBLIC AND THE NATURAL RESOURCES WITHIN THE ONONDAGA LAKE WATERSHED.

ENVIRONMENTAL DNA HAS BEEN PROMOTED AS A METHOD WITH HIGH POTENTIAL FOR CONSERVATION APPLICATIONS INCLUDING EARLY DETECTION OF INVASIVE SPECIES, DETECTION OF CRYPTIC OR RARE SPECIES, COMMUNITY ASSESSMENTS OF SPECIES RICHNESS, SPECIES ABUNDANCE, AND NON-INVASIVE BIOMONITORING. OF PARTICULAR INTEREST IS THE USE OF EDNA FOR MONITORING POPULATIONS AND ASSESSING POPULATION SIZE IN STREAM SYSTEMS. THESE APPLICATIONS REQUIRE KNOWLEDGE ON HOW EDNA BEHAVES AND MOVES IN A PARTICULAR SYSTEM. HOWEVER, STUDIES COMPARING DYE TRACERS AND RELEASED DNA IN EXPERIMENTAL STREAMS INDICATE THAT THE STANDARD MODELS USED TO PREDICT CONSERVATIVE TRACERS DO NOT WORK WELL TO DESCRIBE EDNA MOVEMENT IN FLOWING SYSTEMS. UNDERSTANDING HOW EDNA CHANGES IN RIVERS WILL REQUIRE MODELS THAT INCORPORATE BIOLOGICAL, HYDROLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL PARAMETERS. WE PROPOSE TO BUILD FROM THESE CURRENT MODELING AND MECHANISTIC STUDIES, INCORPORATING MORE COMPLEX HYDROLOGICAL FACTORS TO CREATE AND EVALUATE A MODEL OF FRESHWATER MUSSEL EDNA TRANSPORT AND DETECTION IN THE FIELD.MUSSELS ARE EXCELLENT CANDIDATES FOR STUDY BOTH BECAUSE OF THEIR CONSERVATION SIGNIFICANCE AND BECAUSE ASPECTS OF THEIR DISTRIBUTION AND LIFE HISTORY WILL FACILITATE MODELING AND EXPERIMENTATION. CONSERVATION INTEREST IN FRESHWATER MUSSELS IS HIGH BECAUSE OF THE LARGE NUMBER OF LISTED SPECIES (88 OUT OF 298 FRESHWATER MUSSEL TAXA). POPULATION MONITORING, PROPAGATION, AND REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS ARE ONGOING IN MOST MIDWESTERN AND EASTERN STATES. ADULT MUSSELS ARE EFFECTIVELY IMMOBILE, SO THAT FIELD SAMPLING AND MODELING CAN BE SIMPLIFIED. SEVERAL RECENT STUDIES ON FRESHWATER MUSSEL EDNA MARKERS, SHEDDING, DEGRADATION AND TRANSPORT ARE AVAILABLE TO AID IN MODEL DEVELOPMENT. THE CLINCH RIVER IN NORTHEASTERN TENNESSEE AND SOUTHWESTERN VIRGINIA WILL BE THE PRIMARY STUDY AREA FOR THE PROJECT. THE CLINCH RIVER HAS NUMEROUS SITES OF LISTED SPECIES WITH KNOWN DENSITIES, INCLUDING THE ENDANGERED OYSTER MUSSEL (EPIOBLASMA CAPSAEFORMIS), ONE OF THE MAIN TARGET SPECIES FOR THE PROJECT. THE RIVER AND ITS MUSSEL FAUNA WILL FACILITATE DEVELOPMENT OF THE EDNA FLUX MODEL AND DEVELOPMENT OF EDNA TOOLS FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION RELEVANT TO SERVICE OBJECTIVES. THE FIRST OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TO DETECT THE PRESENCE AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF ENVIRONMENTAL DNA OF MUSSEL SPECIES RESTORED TO SEVERAL SITES IN THE UPPER CLINCH RIVER, VIRGINIA TO DETERMINE HOW DETECTION RATES AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF EDNA CORRELATE WITH TRADITIONAL SAMPLING OF MUSSEL BEDS AND/OR QPCR ANALYSIS OF EDNA. THE SECONDOBJECTIVE IS TO DETERMINE WHAT ARE THE MOST INFORMATIVE SAMPLING DESIGNS AND CONDITIONS (E.G., SEASON, WATER TEMPERATURE, RIVER DISCHARGE, MUSSEL DENSITY, FOOD AVAILABILITY, MUSSEL SPAWNING, ETC.) TO SAMPLE EDNA FOR FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE CLINCH RIVER. ACCOMPLISHMENT OF THESE TWO OBJECTIVES WILL PROVIDE THE SERVICE'S NATURAL RESOURCE DAMAGE ASSESSMENT AND RESTORATION PROGRAM AS WELL AS THE GENERAL WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY WITH EDNA TOOLS THAT CAN BE USED TO MONITOR FRESHWATER MUSSEL SPECIES OF CONCERN IN RIVERS. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON NATIVE MUSSELS, WHICH HAVE SPECIAL CONSERVATION SIGNIFICANCE IN NORTH AMERICA. THE ECOLOGY AND REPRODUCTION OF MUSSELS PROVIDES UNIQUE OPPORTUNITIES FOR DEVELOPING AND TESTING MODELS OF EDNA FLUX IN RIVERS.

IN 2019 THE LAMOILLE COUNTY CONSERVATION DISTRICT (LCCD) COMPLETED THE LAKE EDEN WATERSHED ACTION PLAN. LAKE EDEN IS A PRISTINE LAKE BUT HAS BEEN SHOWING NUTRIENT (I.E. PHOSPHORUS) AND SEDIMENT LOADING STRESSES DUE TO DEVELOPMENT PATTERNS SURROUNDING THE LAKE. THE STUDY ASSESSED AT WHAT LOCATIONS THESE STRESSORS WERE MOST IMPACTFUL BY CONDUCTING ROAD EROSION INVENTORIES, STREAM WALKS AND SHORELINE ASSESSMENTS. TWENTY POSSIBLE PROJECTS WERE IDENTIFIED AND 5 OF THESE THAT RANKED HIGHEST WERE BROUGHT TO 30% DESIGN.THROUGH THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE USFWS, LCCD WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT 4 OUT OF THE 5 PROJECTS IDENTIFIED AT 30% DESIGN AND CREATE A PRELIMINARY DESIGN FOR LOCATIONS IDENTIFIED IN THE PLAN ON BACK SHORE DRIVE, EDEN, VT. IN ADDITION TO THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THESE PROJECTS LCCD WILL PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL SIGNAGE ON 2 OR 3 OF THE MORE PUBLICLY VIEWED PROJECTS.

RARITAN HEADWATERS ASSOCIATION (RHA) HAS WORKED TO PROTECT AND RESTORE WATER QUALITY IN THE NORTH AND SOUTH BRANCH RARITAN RIVER WATERSHED REGION IN NEW JERSEY SINCE 1959. UNDER THIS AGREEMENT, RHA WILL COLLABORATE WITH U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO RESTORE STREAMS AND RIPARIAN HABITAT AND ENHANCE FISH HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND NATIVE BIODIVERSITY IN STREAMS AND RIPARIAN CORRIDORS. RHA WILL USE FUNDS TO HIRE A FULL TIME RESTORATION COORDINATOR TO OVERSEE THE RESTORATION OF FORESTED RIPARIAN BUFFERS ALONG AT LEAST EIGHT MILES OF STREAM IN THE UPPER RARITAN WHERE BUFFERS ARE LACKING OR IN POOR CONDITION. THIS INDIVIDUAL WILL ALSO PLAY A KEY ROLE IN THE PARTICIPATION OF ACTIVITIES TO ADVANCE THE REMOVAL OF SEVERAL DAMS IN THE WATERSHED. USFWS WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE AND PLAY AN ACTIVE ROLE IN THE PROJECT PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. THE INTENDED AWARD PERIOD IS FOUR YEARS.

THIS PROJECT CONSISTS OF THE ACQUISITION AND PERMANENT PROTECTION OF 1,112 ACRES OF TROPICAL RAINFOREST HABITAT WITHIN THE CERRO SAN GIL WATERSHED PROTECTION RESERVE IN THE CARIBBEAN REGION OF GUATEMALA. THIS AREA PROVIDES IMPORTANT WINTERING HABITAT FOR NEOTROPICAL MIGRATORY BIRDS THAT BREED IN VIRGINIA, AND PROTECTING IT WILL HELP PROVIDE FULL LIFE CYCLE CONSERVATION OF THESE MIGRATORY BIRDS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO SUPPORT OTHER CONSERVATION PLANS AND STRATEGIES RELATED TO PRESERVING THE WOOD THRUSH AND FOREST HABITAT IN GUATEMALA. THE ACQUIRED LAND WILL BE ADDED TO THE CERRO SAN GIL RESERVE, REGISTERED AS A PRIVATE NATURE RESERVE AND PERMANENTLY PROTECTED, AND INTEGRATED INTO THE EXISTING LONG-TERM BIRD MONITORING PROGRAM IN THE CERRO SAN GIL AREA. AMERICAN BIRD CONSERVANCY WILL WORK WITH FUNDAECO, A LOCAL PARTNER IN GUATEMALA THAT ABC HAS SUCCESSFULLY WORKED WITH SINCE 2011.

HUMAN POPULATIONS ALONG THE CALIFORNIA COAST CONTINUE TO GROW AND HUMAN USE OF COASTAL 
AREAS HAS POTENTIAL TO CAUSE DISTURBANCE TO SEABIRDS. SEABIRDS USE COASTAL AREAS TO 
ESTABLISH THEIR NESTS AND RAISE THEIR YOUNG TO FLEDGLING AGE. THUS THERE IS NEED TO 
MONITOR NESTS AND HUMAN ACTIVITIES NEAR THE NESTS SO AS TO INFORM PROGRAMS THAT CAN 
MINIMIZE OR ELIMINATE ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCE AND PROTECT VULNERABLE SEABIRD COLONIES 
ALONG THE CENTRAL CALIFORNIA COAST.

THE FOX RIVER GREEN BAY NATURAL RESOURCE TRUSTEES RESTORE NATURAL RESOURCES INJURED BY THE RELEASE OF POLYCHLORINATED BIPHENYLS (PCBS) INTO THE LOWER FOX RIVER AND GREEN BAY, WI. THE TRUSTEES ALLOCATE FUNDING, PROVIDED BY SETTLEMENT DOLLARS FROM RESPONSIBLE PARTIES, TO RESTORATION PROJECTS THAT FULFILL THE NATURAL RESOURCE OBJECTIVES OF THE 2003 JOINT
RESTORATION PLAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT FOR THE LOWER FOX RIVER AND GREEN BAY AREA AND THE 2016 RESTORATION PLAN UPDATE UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF THE COMPREHENSIVE ENVIRONMENTAL RESPONSE, COMPENSATION AND LIABILITY ACT. A COPY OF THE RESTORATION PLAN AND UPDATE CAN BE FOUND AT FOXRIVERNRDA.ORG OR PROVIDED BY THE AGENCY CONTACT BY REQUEST. THIS IS NOT A
CONVENTIONAL GRANTS PROGRAM, IN THAT IT DOES NOT SOLICIT FOR PROJECTS THROUGH A FORMAL REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS ON GRANTS.GOV; INSTEAD, PROJECT IDEA FORMS ARE DEVELOPED STRATEGICALLY IN COORDINATION WITH THE TRUSTEE COUNCIL. PROJECTS
THAT ARE FUNDED THROUGH THE NRDA PROGRAM MUST BE WITHIN THE PCB AFFECTED AREA AND MUST REPLACE, RESTORE, OR ACQUIRE THE EQUIVALENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES INJURED BY THE RELEASE OF PCBS. PROJECTS UNDERGO A SELECTION PROCESS BASED ON THE CRITERIA OUTLINED IN THE NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY (NOFO).
